body: @guozhangwang these are simple string changes from feedback during documentation review. E.g., qps->rate. time->latency. Nothing major and no correctness changes. Thanks.

Updated, some [minor refactoring](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2425/commits/b13e3396c387a649c22784c5f15fa1a75bba13b9) and a new [unit test](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2425/commits/2c7149e165a5743c8c6319aff03b2fbee589405c) as suggested.
@guozhangwang @mjsax @enothereska - this might be what is sometimes causing the latest build failures due to `pure virtual method call`. In any case, it should close the stores.

I ran the ducktape tests in Docker and they all passed:

```
KAFKA_IMAGE_REBUILD=1 TC_PATHS="tests/kafkatest/tests/client/client_compatibility_features_test.py" bash ./tests/docker/run_tests.sh
KAFKA_IMAGE_REBUILD=1 TC_PATHS="tests/kafkatest/tests/client/client_compatibility_produce_consume_test.py" bash ./tests/docker/run_tests.sh
```

LGTM. Thanks for the patch.

@ijuma As you know Apache Kafka uses outdated metrics lib, which is not an issue on production but produces lots of troubles on functional and unit testing. Codahale metrics is a popular enough library. If an application depends on metrics 3.x, it will shadow Kafka metrics, which ,of course, produces exceptions. 
The PR does not changing the names of the metrics but removes some subnames due to changes in the library. Perhaps, you're right and a KIP should be created.

Discussed with @enothereska offline about the naming of `addLatencySensor` and `recordLatency`, in which throughput metrics are recorded as well. Eno, could you update KIP-114 wiki and reply to the vote email thread about this change as well?
LGTM, thanks for cleaning this up!
Merged to trunk and 0.10.2, thanks @jeyhunkarimov !

Thanks @jeyhunkarimov , the patch itself looks promising to me.

I think we need to think a bit more whether we should be "dropping records" or "raise exception" for all cases. To me the former makes sense if users would only put null key by mistake and hence would not care about those records. But I have not seen much of these scenarios so would want to hear other's opinion: @dguy @enothereska 

If we go with the "dropping records" direction, then I think we should add a metric for this case. Note we already have a thread-level "skippedRecordsSensor", and this processorNode-level sensor should add it as its parent.
@vahidhashemian  Thanks. so can we close this PR now?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.11/1174/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.11).
In my opinion, `0` is a reasonable default value for such metrics. Anyway please have me updated if any further discussion is needed.

The general solution looks good to me. I am fine with `InternalTopologyBuilder` and `InternalKStreamBuilder`.

> I agree, that in final refactoring, runtime should be have any idea if a topology was build via TopologyBuilder or KStreamBuilder -- this is not the case right now and not completely fixed by this PR yet -- it's still WIP.

You mean "runtime should not have any idea"?

> There a still some abstractions that are messy -- the final goal would be to have a clear separation of TopologyBuilder and the DSL

One thing worth considering though, is that today we have seen some users using `addProcessor` and `KStream/KTable` interleavingly with `KStreamBuilder`. Honestly I think this is not a good pattern but would like to have us think what would potentially be restricted if we do not let `KStreamBuilder` to extend from `TopologyBuilder` anymore.
Any update on this?

For your questions:
1: No, new consumer does not use ZK anymore. The fix is only for old consumer. Old consumer without group id specified leaves a lot of "garage" under /consumers due to the fact that `ZKUtils.deletePath` failed to delete them.
2: Yes. Tests showed that `AdminUtils.deleteConsumerGroupInZK` was able to clean up all the unused zk paths.

As what I said above, I am not sure if you guys still want to check in any code for fixing old consumer problems, especially when community is planning to remove it recently. It's up to you. If you don't, I am free to close the PR.
Does it make any sense?
